abstract: Stocks on Wall Street fell on Tuesday and the euro retreated to a new low, in part after Germany moved to impose tighter regulation of financial markets.
snippet: Stocks on Wall Street fell on Tuesday and the euro retreated to a new low, in part after Germany moved to impose tighter regulation of financial markets.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street fell on Tuesday and the euro retreated to a new low, in part after Germany moved to impose tighter regulation of financial markets, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser and David Jolly reported.

headline.main: U.S. Stocks Fall Amid New Concern About Europe

abstract: Shorebank, a troubled Chicago community bank with a philanthropic reputation, has won uncommon Wall Street backing to save it from a government takeover, while similarly sized rivals fail.
snippet: Shorebank, a troubled Chicago community bank with a philanthropic reputation, has won uncommon Wall Street backing to save it from a government takeover, while similarly sized rivals fail.
lead_paragraph: A troubled Chicago community bank with a philanthropic reputation has won uncommon Wall Street backing to save it from a government takeover, while similarly sized rivals flounder and fail, Reuters reports.

abstract: Bank of America agreed to sell preferred and common shares of Brazil’s Itau Unibanco in a deal valued at $4.5 billion, ending a partnership started in 2006, Reuters reported.
snippet: Bank of America agreed to sell preferred and common shares of Brazil’s Itau Unibanco in a deal valued at $4.5 billion, ending a partnership started in 2006, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America agreed to sell preferred and common shares of Brazil’s Itau Unibanco in a deal valued at 8.16 billion reais ($4.5 billion), ending a partnership started in 2006 when the Brazilian bank took over the local unit of FleetBoston Financial, Reuters reported.

headline.main: BofA Said to Sell $4.5 Billion Stake in Brazil’s Itau

abstract: The Senate shouldn’t neglect strengthening derivatives rules, especially as efforts to overhaul financial regulation enter the final stretch, The New York Times editorial board argues.
snippet: The Senate shouldn’t neglect strengthening derivatives rules, especially as efforts to overhaul financial regulation enter the final stretch, The New York Times editorial board argues.
lead_paragraph: It is a bad sign, as the Senate enters the home stretch on financial regulatory reform, that there are so many unresolved issues since weaknesses and ambiguities in the legislation play into the hands of opponents of reform at this late date.

headline.main: The Senate at the Finish Line
